segments.text: I'm Richard Dick Buck Wirus Lund.
All those names are somewhere involved with me because I was born Richard Wirus Lund in August the 29th, 1920, in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
And as a child, I was called Sonny.
I was called Richard.
And then in school, I was called Dick.
In high school, through various songs and funny things of my stature, the name Buck came up.
It was a derivative of Buckskin, which was a little song in those days.
But anyway, that's not necessary for this purpose.
But anyway, the name Buck came up.
And then at A&M, I was called Buck for the last couple of years because it's always Fishwires, or Fish Jones, Fish Detloff,
in the early part of your college career.
But the Lund is... Lund is my father's name.
L-U-N-D. D. Uh-huh.
L-U-N-D. And he came from Dawson, Minnesota, and my mother came from Thief River Falls, Minnesota.
She was born in Eau Claire, Wisconsin, but she was raised...
Her father, my grandfather, Wyrus, was a railroad man, the Sioux Line Railroad.
His family had come from Alsace, and they had been
brewmasters and winemakers and so on.
But when he got to Wisconsin, somehow or another, he didn't continue in that.
He got into the railroad business and built cofferdams for bridges and so on.
But anyway, the name Wirus was this name.
My mother and father were divorced in 1923, which was unusual for those days.
My mother was an early woman's libber.
And she had me by court decree.
So I lived with her family most of the time until 1934.
And that was, I lived with an Indian family.
And you were where in Minnesota?
In Minnesota, in Minneapolis.
Minneapolis.
And I lived with an Indian family.
And they were Chippewa Indians.
And she was a nurse, and they were off the reservation.
But they did Chautauquas.
And he played football with Jim Thorpe.
at Carlisle.
And of course I learned a lot of Indian lore because they did Chautauquas.
And I got to be in those Chautauquas and had a little suit and we did the different dances.
Oh, we know.
But this is a side of you I never knew.
That's interesting.
And it was real interesting for me.
My first memory of it was at Prior Lake and there was a group of Indians there.
And these people of course were all educated, but they were like
you would imagine they were quite clannish.
And I remember Maude, their name was P-E-A-K-E, was their American.
His Indian name was Chief Little Moose.
And of course, squaws didn't seem to get those exotic names like Little Moose.
Did you keep contact with those people over?
Yes, I did.
The last one I have is a girl my age.
She graduated from the University of Minnesota.
and worked for the Ford Motor Company there in Minneapolis for many, many years.
And I kept up with her until about 10, 12 years ago.
And her Indian name was Abidu.
Abidu.
P-E-A-K-E.
But there were two families, two brothers, and I kept in touch with the brothers' family.
No.
Louise, yeah.
Yeah, Louise Peake was the sister-in-law of the family that I grew up with.
Anyway, I was there until

to Lindbergh across the ocean that was in 1926 and 27 and then my mother moved me she got she got ill in Chicago my grandpa I went down I was there almost a school year went to kindergarten in Chicago and my grandfather took me then to the farm in Wisconsin uh Colfax Wisconsin which is near
Eau Claire, Menominee, and Chippewa Falls, it's due east of Minneapolis about 75 miles.
Now it would be out that interstate that goes east out of Minneapolis.
Yeah, I think I've taken that.
Uh-huh.
It goes right by Menominee and Eau Claire.
Chippewa Falls sits off to the left.
Yeah, to the left.
That's pretty country.
Oh, it's just beautiful.
And of course, I was living in heaven.
A little kid, 14 years old, finished the eighth grade in a one-room school.
The closest paved road was about 12 miles away.
It would be Menominee.
all the other roads were dirt roads.
They were county roads and township roads.
We had a township road, which got a grader about every six months.
The rest of it was just old dust and gravel, you know.
And this is interesting.
There was a one-room building, and these schools were scattered just about two to four miles apart.
The teachers
were normal school educated.
They had two years, but all of them had taken special music.
They taught everything from music and drama to agriculture and sports.
And she was a Norwegian lady, Minda Berg was her name, lived to be 92 or 93 years old, died a couple of years ago.
But you talk about excellence in education, there were an average of 30 children in that
I'm going to meet with my classmates this summer.
In that school?
Is that right?
We're going to have a little reunion up on a farm there near Menominee.
She had all eight grades.
All the kids got to walk to school at least a mile, except me.
I lived across the road, so that made me the janitor, for which I got paid 25 cents a day, and they thought that was too much.
So they reduced my salary to 15 cents a day.
I swept the school and dusted and then had to clean the blackboards and build the fire.
Now, the other boys put the wood down the chute to the furnace.
We didn't have a furnace in the basement.
No plumbing and no electricity.
And so we had outdoor back houses and we had great windows.
It was cold in the wintertime.
Yeah.
Then they set up the fire for me.
And all I came in the morning was going to put kerosene on the wood and then set the fire.
Went and did my milking, just about 100 yards away from my house to the school.
And then after a milking, usually four cows was about mine at that age.
I got the easy milkers, so my uncle took the heifers.
They're the hardest ones.
But we didn't have a milking machine.
Of course, now everything is electric.
automated.
And it's these farms.
Did he run a dairy?
It was a dairy, Guernsey Cattle.
So we had to study agriculture, one of the courses.
But she did about 20 recitations a day.
And those recitations seemed to me averaged between, say, 10 and 20 minutes.
But I can't remember.
But I remember everybody had at least, oh, eight grades.
We'd have two or so recitations every day.
And of course a lot of our work in arithmetic was done at the blackboard.
Which kept you on your toes.
You couldn't doze in class.
We did all our studying there.
I never studied at home.
I didn't have anybody really to help me at home.
My uncle did finish high school, but my grandparents hadn't.
He was busy with women and things like that.
So I didn't have any help at home.
But anyway, this group, all six of us that finished eighth grade in 1934 are living.
All of us finished college.
And we were quite successful.
Everett Iverson, the man I'm going to meet this summer, was head of instruction.
Ran through Illinois, Scott Air Force Base, the training for Air Force technicians.
And his cousin, who was the grade behind us, was superintendent of schools over in Pontiac, Michigan.
Anyway.
That's interesting.
Yeah.
But you've even kept that contact.
It's incredible.
Well, I've kept contact with people.
See, because everywhere I met, everyone was my family.
I didn't really have a family at home.
I've never really had.
For example, my family in my later years were high school and Texas A&M.
That's why I've been such a devoted former student, that I immediately found friends.
And then in 1934, when I finished the eighth grade,
My mother wanted me to come to Texas to be with her.
She said the reason for that was that I wouldn't know I had a mother, which is quite true.
How'd she get to Texas?
She came here selling knitback hose mending machines.
And silk hosiery was the fashion in those days, and they were quite expensive.
A good pair of silk hose would be, average price, about $12.50.
And if a woman snagged it like they would a nylon today, then they could afford to pay $1 or $0.50 or $1 to get it fixed.
And this hose mending machine, you could also do it by hand, had a little latched hook, and you could hook into the runner and knit it back right up to the top.
And then with a fine silk thread, you could do an invisible mend behind it that you couldn't see once the lady had put the hoser back on her feet.
And these machines were small, intricate machines and took a lot of training.
So when she sold a machine,
She had to stay to train people on it and so on.
And so she was way ahead of her time.
She sold paint, DuPont, Valentine.
She really was, yeah.
I've got a picture of her painting the Ford in 1926, Model T Ford, well, black, of course.
Oh, yeah.
But they could paint them with a brush because the paint wouldn't, that Duco paint was good.
So anyway.

uh so i came to texas in 1934. and we're in san antonio uh-huh she was set up in the old hicks building which was on the corner of broadway and houston on the third floor and had uh oh three girls doing re-weaving she got that franchise from washington they see a friend of hers a friend of theirs had this uh process of taking threads or material from the garment and re-weaving the whole or damaged
anything from a bullet hole to a cigarette burn, usually on new clothes or good clothes, because you were using new threads from the chin seams and lapels, and if it was worn too much, it would show.
The new threads would show against the worn threads.
So new, good clothes, but it was difficult to do.
It's a lost art now.
There's only one girl.
I sold the business when I moved to A&M in 1961.
which was involved in a mail order business.
And we did it for the tailors and better stores.
I say better stores because a less expensive suit's not worth spending $5, $10 to get it rewoven.
So anyway, I did her pickup and deliveries.
That was my first job in San Antonio was to, my allowance was based on my pickup and deliveries every day, which I walked down Houston Street over to,
to the ladies' stores on Houston Street, to Sears up to Joski's, and the men's stores on Alamo Plaza, after school.
And of course when I got in the ROTC we had drum corps and drill practice after school.
What school did you go to?
Central Catholic High School.
I was very unhappy when I got there.
My next question, I'm going to ask you how you felt about all that.
Well I didn't feel well about it at all because I wasn't given any choice.
My choice would have been I had my dog, fishing
Yeah, you were happy.
A river that ran through the farm.
It was just heaven for a kid.
You know, I had my rifle.
I had a .22 rifle.
I had a little .410 shotgun, and here I was.
And then all of a sudden they're going to send me to this strange place.
I read Zane Gray novels all the way down here and expecting to see that.
Everybody still does, I meant.
Just another big city.
So I was very unhappy and wanted to go home.
And I guess in my little mind figured,
If I misbehaved and didn't stay, she'd send me back.
And she outfoxed me.
She put me in Central Catholic High School.
Then the brothers and priests.
Were those sisters?
Okay, were they sisters or brothers?
Brothers and priests.
All brothers and priests.
So when they took over, you did your homework.
Yes, sir, I bet you did.
If you started messing up, the principal went in and he had my favorite, most not favorite weapon, the razor strap, was on the wall.
Yes.

so kept you in line well but the best thing is that i met these wonderful young boys who befriended me and took me right into there and made me feel like one of them even though i wasn't a catholic so but i mean i still have the afraid i make every high school reunion we have one about every three four months there's only about 25 of us left living out of 82 that finished in 1938 yeah so uh yeah i
I made these wonderful friends that I still communicate with, talk to, in fact, once a week.
So things got better for you?
Oh, yeah, right away.
The ROTC gave me equality.
We all had the same uniform, and I learned if I'd press my uniform, it could pass inspect, shoe shine, brass shine, belt buckle shine.
But I could win inspections, and I made corporal in my first year.
Then first sergeant my next year and so on.
So ROTC was a big factor.
In fact, the military has been a big factor all my life.
That's probably one of the few schools with a high school ROTC.
Oh, no.
All of them had them.
Public high schools had them, too.
Is that right?
Jefferson High School and Breckenridge and Texas Military and Peacock Military.
I don't remember any in Louisiana.
Well, LSU's probably still the only school left that has compulsory first two years ROTC.
That's right.
Yeah, I knew that.
But there's no Corps of Cadets there.
I don't think there has been in many years.
But they may still have required that.
But except the Pentagon's not too interested in teaching citizenship.
That's what that is, really.
It's a good thing to know, because you learn first aid, discipline, and all that.
But anyway, so from high school ROTC,
There was a couple of fellas had brothers at A&M, older brothers.
And I saw a man named Charlie Stout, S-T-O-U-D-T, Stout.
This guy was my same age.
He was my neighbor.
He didn't go to Central.
He went to Jefferson.
But his brother came home with his A&M, had the boots on and the britches and this dark olive green shirt.
And the campaign hat, I thought, if I could ever look like that, wouldn't that be something?
So I was kind of led to A&M by the uniform and the ROTC.
I knew pretty well, because I already knew how to march and do all the commands.
In those days, it was very difficult.
When you drilled, you didn't have just a right face forward march.
It would be right face.
You have to give the command for your rifles.
But in those days, we used squads.
It was right by squads and a column of squads, right platoon, right by.
Very difficult.
You had to really read the manual and practice a lot to be the pizit man.
I can imagine.
Yeah.
So anyway, the ROTC is what led me to A&M in 1938.
And I was very confused, and I was having so much fun.
of being a sorry freshman, not doing what I was supposed to do, and not getting caught much at it, because I found out when they were hazing, that's when I was janitor.
You see, I was janitor at the Petroleum Engineering Building, and I missed all of the little programs where you might be.
So I was always at seeing cadets, or I was always going someplace and stayed away from the dorm during those hectic hours.
But they didn't bother me a whole lot.
I just had a lot of fun.
When I found out right off, I didn't think I ought to be an engineer.
And about my sophomore year, I knew I wasn't going to be an engineer.
So I went and talked to the dean.
He said, I told him I wanted to change to liberal arts.
And he said, well, you're going to lose practically half of what you've taken.
But if you switch to industrial education, you won't lose anything.
So go talk to E.L. Williams and see if he'll take you.
So at the end of my sophomore year, I changed courses.
Who was the dean?
Do you remember?
Dean Gilchrist.
Gilchrist was the dean.
And Dean Bolton was dean of the college.
G.O.
Walton was president.
And George Moore was commandant, class of, what, class of 06 or something?
Eight, class of eight, I think.
So in those days, of course, it was all military.
We did have some postgraduate students that were working on master's degrees in engineering or agriculture.
And I guess they gave a doctorate in those days.
I'm not sure.
And we had veterinary medicine students that lived in what they called postgraduate hall.
Called it PG Hall over behind Walton.
It was a wooden building.
Pretty nice building.
But I made such good friends here, just like high school.
But really, if I could do it over again, I would have majored in liberal arts, because I really enjoyed it more than I did.
I enjoyed history more and more.
I'll just say that I was more motivated on those subjects than I was.
You might have ended up a college professor or something.
You're probably better off where you went.
My roommate did, Dave Finch.
Anyway, my impression then of A&M was it was a place of high concern for knowledge.

I mean, everybody was concerned about their grades and studying and a lot of emphasis by the upperclassmen to see that the freshmen were in their rooms at night and at least had a book open in front of them.
You can't make them read, but you can certainly make sure they got a book.
make sure that they go to class because their schedules are posted on the door.
Now, they're each room, each student's schedule.
Do you think that that kind of concern slacked off for some time after the war or was persisting?
Because, you know, that was one of the criticisms leveled at the core, that they didn't stress education.
There was too much distraction in the 60s and 70s, I know, when I was there.
I don't know.
That's part of just the general...
I can't really address myself to that specifically because...
I never had the feeling that, I thought that there always was a certain percentage of students that were real, highly motivated.
Well I think so too.
And my guess is that at that time people came to school realizing this was their big opportunity.
I'll say this though, there was an element in most outfits that took the hazing and the
shouting matches and things like that, what they called good bull, took that pretty seriously.
And that a shy freshman, very timid or backward, would have a difficulty in responding to that.
He took it too seriously.
And I think I always took it as fun.
I thought it was a play or acting and things like that because of the stern faces

scolding and freshman year so so i thought that was good so that when you got to be a sophomore you had to learn to make make the ugly face and demand attention and all that stuff but some of the sophomores went overboard sure and this caused a lot of distraction and it did cause a lot of people to leave school in those days they couldn't leave the corps they had to leave school period yeah so i think it was a
I just think it was overdone for several years.
But it's hard to be specific about this.
In generalities, I thought there was a great deal of consternation in the administration.
If you look at the history, you'll see that the Corps was compulsory, and then it was non-compulsory.
They tried that for a while.
The big thing you notice is that they had a commandant, such as they have today, a man named
Well, when I was in school, it was all military.
Active duty, like General Moore.
Colonel Moore was active duty.
But after the war, a man named Joe Davis was class of 29, became commandant.
And he was a state employee paid by the university, and his staff were all non-active duty, except for the ROTC instructors.
They were active duty.
So you had a mixture, like we do today.
You have the instructors in the classroom,
The staff, the... Vannevar mentioned that as a very important element in the core relationship, was that it be a university employee who's in authority.
Like we have now, General Darling, even though he's retired, he's not on active duty.
And remember when Colonel Parsons was here, the former students and others were telling him what had to happen in the Corps and having programs help the Corps.
He says, wait a minute.
He said, my boss is a commanding general, 4th Army.
I work for him.
Now, he says, my secondary boss is the dean of students and the president of the university.
He said, I report to them.
But he said, they're not immediately who signs my paycheck.
That makes a difference.
Yes.
And he said, I have a staff here.
We'll take care of things in the Corps.

but he said i don't need any outside pressures and influence tell me how to run the court he says i can be relieved and replaced but as long as i'm in command as long as i'm here in charge why don't listen and uh i kind of feel that way today i'm not concerned about the core that's general darling and his staff he has staff of very capable people and he's certainly a highly qualified man and he's going to do the right he's going to do the very best he can because in this
changing world of youth, youth world.
It's all different.
But so the fact we have a corps is commendable.
And I'll say one thing, the quality is sheer high.
It's not as big as we'd like for it to be, but the people I know in the corps are certainly outstanding.
I want to come back to that.
1938, and you're going to be in school through 1941.
I wasn't able to have a contract.
I wasn't classified my junior year.
So I got a contract my senior year.
And I graduated in January of 43 with a class of 43.
That's why I go to both reunions.
And I have equal friends in both classes.
Of course, actually, the truth is I go to 41, 42, 43, and 44.
All the above.
Yeah.
I've been to several student meetings, and they're always asking me questions about what was it like then, and what does the future look like?
That's what I'm going to ask you.
I'm glad you've been thinking about it.
So you graduated in 43.
Yes.
Went right into active duty.
See, we didn't have any summer camp, the six-week summer camp that was required for ROTC reserve commissions.
So the Army didn't know what in the world to do, except they decided, because they had the OCS program going and the OCS curriculum was the same as the company officer's course.
The difference was the OCS required a little more discipline and a little more harassment and so on.
But the basic studies in communications and motor transport and organization and gunnery was exactly the same as the battery officer's course.
They did two things.
They made corporals so we could be admitted to OCS.
We were inducted as privates in our closest place.
Houston was Ellington Field, and San Antonio was Fort Sam Houston, and so on.
Every major city had an induction station.
We were all inducted in the service and issued a uniform and made corporals and sent to basic schools.
I went to Fort Sill, Oklahoma, to the artillery school.
Others went to Fort Benning, others went to Fort Monmouth, Signal Corps, Coastal Artillery went down to Galveston, Fort Crockett, and so on.
We reported there to OCS.
All the basic arms, like Fort Knox was the armored school, and Fort Riley was the cavalry.
By the way, a lot of them went into tank destroyer school at Fort Hood.
which used anti-tank guns with the infantry, and they were organized in battalions and companies.
So when did you get your orders to OCS, before graduation and everything?
Was this all pretty well?
Well, it was all laid out, but we didn't actually get them until we graduated with our, in Guyon Hall.
We were given a couple of tickets for our family, because Guyon Hall didn't hold very many people, because the graduates took up about 600, I guess, in our class that graduated.
And everybody
that finished at that time, even though they hadn't graduated, went on active duty.
But then they came back after one graduated.
And we had to go to our nearest station, and there we were inducted.
Then from there, we went by train to our various posts.
And so the answer is no.
We had to report to the induction station.
for induction into the Army.
From there, we got our orders.
We got orders for promotion to corporal and for report to Fort Sill, Oklahoma, for testing, physicals.
We'd already taken one physical up there.
They gave us an officer's physical.
It was a little different, a little more extensive.
And we took mathematics quizzes and exams for trigonometry and algebra and geometry.
mainly because artillery has a lot of that in it.
And you were in OCS for, is it six weeks?
Yeah, we went in in January, and we, no, no, three and a half months.
Three and a half months, okay.
See, January 23rd to May the 6th.
Yeah, nearly four months, yeah.
And at the end you got your orders.
We got our orders, and they were commissioned second lieutenants,
and the United States Army Reserve.
And we were given assignments.
Most of them were to the replacement training center and officer pools, further education.
And most of us went to training centers.
In my case, it was the Field Artillery Replacement Training Center in Fort Sill, where we trained everything from cooks to bakers and linemen and gun crews and things like that.
And then from there, the men were shipped out as replacements.
outfits activated, repenting activation in the United States, and some of them went to Europe.
I was going to ask you, did most of those out of Fort Sill go to Europe or the Pacific, or both, I guess?
Yeah, about half.
It was just a requisition filled either way by personnel, but Europe took the most.
Of course, as it had gotten up time for the invasion, Europe was...
I got my orders...
Let's see, in May of 44, May, was that right?
Yeah, well, April, really, April 44, I got my orders to report to Fort Hamilton, New York as a replacement.
And the next morning, I was supposed to get on the train on Saturday morning, and they knocked on my door at 5 o'clock and gave me orders changing, I guess, all of us, about 50 of us,
were being transferred to Camp Breckenridge, Kentucky, to a field artillery group pending activation.
And we didn't know it then, but these battalions about, let's see, there were eight battalions there.
There was eight battalions at Camp Chaffee.
Sixteen battalions were activated, organized from enlisted men that were in the West Coast Harbor Defense, that is, the Coast Artillery men.
And these men were inducted
I mean, transferred to field artillery.
These battalions were to reinforce the fires of the Rhine River crossing.
They were 155 howitzer and 8-inch howitzer.
That's medium and heavy artillery to reinforce the fires.
There wasn't enough corps artillery to concentrate as much as they needed for such an undertaking as crossing the Rhine River.
They didn't know where that was going to be.
And they had several sites.
It depended on the whole situation as to which site they could use.
And we were, but as it turned out, we were too late by the time we got to the Red River.
They had long since, because they got the Remagen Bridge.
So that, we were just, we were a month too late.
We cruised past that a couple years ago and took that Rhine cruise, and that thing's still hanging out there.
It's interesting.
Isn't that really?
You can't tell how many lives that saved.
Imagine that.
would have been crossing that river.
But see, this gave them time to get in the two pontoon bridges.
They got those in right away.
Boy, they couldn't have done it with the enemy fire on them and artillery and everything else they had on them.
Okay, so you did go to Kentucky, though, Camp Breckenridge.
Oh, yeah.
And then what happened?
We came back to Fort Sill.
And you came back to Fort Sill.
As school troops.
And then we had to come to Fort Hood to take our battery test.
And so we didn't get overseas, you see, until the fall of 1944.
And that's why we were too late for the Rhine River crossing.
And then we came back in 1945.
Where did they bring you in?
In France, Holland?
Yes, we went into La Harpe.
Yeah, that's where almost everybody was.
The equipment ships, in fact, our ship was
delayed, and we had to go from Southampton.
They sent us across to Dieppe.
And we stayed in the abattoir, the slaughterhouse, was our controlment area, which was about, I imagine, about 50 kilometers or so from Laharm.
And then I took a skeleton gun crew and went down with our equipment ship, came in there to unload them and get the cosmoline off and get them prepared to go up
to move into Germany.
So they sent you from there to the front?
Yeah.
And what army?
Well, we were in the 20th Corps, and that corps was moved from one army to another.
We ended up in the 3rd Army, and the 22nd Corps was also there.
We were in that for a little while.
They would shift these battalions and these groups of artillery depending on the need for it.
See, in the Battle of the Balls, they didn't need, they needed ammunition more than they needed anymore.
And so in order to get the ammunition, well, they just switched all these battalions to the north and were coming up, I guess, sort of behind the Third Army, the 20th Corps.
You know, when you're at that level, you don't really know a lot of this.
No, you don't ask.
It wasn't until I read the history of World War II to find out.
Yeah, what you had done.
Okay, so you were in Germany then until...
until August of 1945.
Where were you when the war ended?
We were right there at Burncastle on the Moselle.
Beautiful, beautiful.

We were supposed to be security guards, and our main problem was keeping our enlisted men away from the military government people, because the military government was supposed to enforce the fraternization order.
And we weren't supposed to fraternize with the German citizens.
Well, those beautiful German girls and our men hadn't been around ladies, so this caused a problem.
Because I was a captain, and so the military government was a captain, and he was fussing about my men walking down the street with these German girls, so I had to get that correct.
Then he wanted us to court-martial one of them, and I had more to do.
We were looking mainly for S.S.
people that had escaped.
They had a big concentration.
We went up on Bad Neuheim.
There was a big POW camp there.
And they just screened them temporarily.
They were looking for SS.
And they screened all these men.
It was right in the summer of 45 there.
It was real warm.
And some interesting things happened.
They had a whole compound of German women who had been in the anti-aircraft artillery.
They were gun crews for 88 millimeters.
and other anti-aircraft weapons.
And they'd take sun baths, and these German men would get over in their compound and startle them, you know.
And the ladies sometimes had their bras unhooked, and this caused hilariousit was sexual harassment is what it was.
And how long did they keep you in Germany now after the war?
Well, we came back to go to Japan.
Oh, okay.
They pulled you right out.
Yeah.
We should have stayed, but we didn't.
We were actually on the high seas.
We came back to Le Havre again, and we were on our way to someplace in the Pacific.
And so they turned us in.
We came into Charleston, South Carolina instead of going through New York or
We didn't get to the Panama Canal.
See, we were on the high seas someplace.
And they diverted us into Charleston.
We ended up in Camp Beale, California.
You took the train?
Uh-huh, took the train from Charleston to Camp Beale.
And then in Camp Beale, what month is that?
Do you remember?
Oh, yeah, just about the time they dropped the A-bomb.
Okay, August.
August, yeah.
Forty-five.
Uh-huh.
So you were on the way, though.
I was on the way, yeah, yeah.
Oh, they just had hundreds of ships, maybe more than hundreds.
And your war ended in California?
In California, yeah.

And then they transferred everybody, I guess, in September, October, maybe in the fall there, September, October, because I remember coming to a football game down here at College Station from Fort Hood.
They transferred us to Fort Hood, Texas, and we joined the 2nd Armored Division.
at Fort Hood.
And in other words, we were integrated, you might say, into the Second Army Division.
And then later, we stayed in and reorganized, restructured.
I didn't get out of the Army until a year later.
When was my next question?
Oh, OK. And had you any option?
Yes, I could have stayed in if I would have taken the exams for integration into regular service.
And I really wanted to in a way, but my wife's family was overseas, her mother and father.
He was in the engineer corps.
And my situation was very difficult.
She had a baby while I was gone.
And as soon as I got home, there was another one.
And so I would have had to go to Korea.
And so I couldn't have taken any family with me.
So I decided I'd abandon her enough, and so I got out of the Army then.
But I went right into the Reserve.
That was in August, you said, of 46.
No, let's see, October, September, the fall of 46.
And so you're coming back to San Antonio?
Came back to San Antonio, uh-huh.
And I took over my mother's weaving business, and I got that.
going again and got some girls trained.
I had a girl in Omaha, Nebraska that came down.
She was the best one we ever had.
We had her during the war.
Her husband was in the Army there at Fort Sam.
So once she got two or three good girls trained, plus myself and my wife, we all learned this reweaving technique.
Hose mending was pretty well out of the business by then because nylons had come on the scene.
And nylons were inexpensive.
They were cheap, you might say.
And silk hosiery was just too expensive.
And so the hose mending went up, but the reweaving business was pretty good.
But like any other small business, it didn't work too well for me because labor costs, you had to pay at least 50% labor.
Then by the time you got workman's comp, and if you had three or more employees, you had to have unemployment comp, and you had to have a hospitalization.
See, this is not new.
We had to do all these things in those days.
We had to take out withholding taxes, social security.
And I had a high school classmate of mine who helped me with all that sort of regulations and bookkeeping that a business had to have, because I hadn't taken any business courses at A&M.
So I had to get a CPA to help me set up my books and help me with the forms I needed for all of that.
But I just didn't make much money out of it.
So in 1948, I had a chance for a wonderful job with the state.
This was organizing National Guard units, and this is where my knowledge of A&M men came in.
So we organized units in the Rio Grande Valley and out in West Texas.
And actually, I was doing that when the- What was your rank when you left service?
Captain.
Actually, when I went in the reserve, I got promoted to major.
And let's see.
Oh yeah, then I went to work for the, I went back in the Army again in 51.
But you were with the state, with the National Guard until 51.
Uh-huh, from 48 to 51.
And I was on active duty through 54, 55, 55.
Yeah, I got out in 55.
And what rank are you now?
Lieutenant Colonel.
And where were you most of the time, 51 to 55?
No, mostly I was in the
I was in Fort Sill, and I was in Fort Knox mostly.
I stayed at Fort Knox.
I went to the armored school.
I've got my certificate at Fort Knox.
And then I stayed there for quite a while and went to Europe with a crew on temporary duty.
And I came back and took some special courses in nuclear weapons.
And then I went to Command General Staff School for a year.
So that took up my time.
I did not go to Korea.
I had a terrible guilty conscience about that.
No more.
So you're going to get out in 55.
Yeah.
And I went to work for the City Public Service Board in San Antonio in the personnel department.
What were you doing there?
Well, actually, I was training.
I had to take the cadet course and go through the whole company and write
papers and dissertations on each department.
What was the title again?
Gas and Electric Utility of Bexar County.
And that was real interesting to me.
I really enjoyed, I was a real education in electrical engineering, mechanics, understanding power plants, electric distribution, and the underground systems of big cities and certain
the elite neighborhoods that had underground electric transformers underground and distribution underground and everything.
I was mystified by that, how the tunnels, they tunneled under the cities and put all that stuff together.
You never think about it, do you?
Also, I can look at a power line and know what wattage it's carrying and understand the different transformers.
They reduce it down to the 220, the 110 that brings it in the house.
you distributed about 4,000 KW.
So it was real education for me.
And the gas distribution, too.
See, they had the gas company.
And these were not really owned by the city, because the bonding company, the Harris Trust of Chicago, really owned those companies, because they didn't cost the city a penny.
See, they were all bond, municipal bonds, or construction bonds.
The money was borrowed, paid back by revenues.
Then excess revenues were given to the city in lieu of taxes, as opposed to a private power company like Houston Lighting and Power and so on.
San Antonio actually was, well, you could say city-owned because it was called City Public Service Board, gas and electric.
The city owned the water, too, of course.
Private investment.
It was very efficient, and it was operated under the same structure that a private company was, modeled after the same employee situation and the same qualifications.
So how long did you stay with the city?
Well, I stayed with them until 1959, and I had a chance to go to an advertising company, a sharp company out of Austin.
gave me the chance to sell advertising for school book covers and other institutional advertising.
I had to travel throughout South Texas.
It was called Sharp?
SHARP, Sharpton Company.
Are they still there?
I don't think so.
I don't think so.
The people who owned it are notin fact, that man was a lawyer.
Bill Pittenger was a lawyer.
But it was a pretty good deal.
It made good money.
Yeah, I traveled to San Antonio and all of South Texas.
I called on institutional advertisers and school superintendents.
And I sold really whatever they cut me.
They didn't have different, like Coca-Cola or the big banks and so on like that.
We sold some billboards.
So they were kind of a multimedia company.
But the big thing was the school book covers.
They had a big printing shop there.
And they printed and distributed these school book covers all over Texas.
It was law that they had to, and that was really nice.
That gave me more time to devote to A&M.
Actually, I was president of the San Antonio A&M Club when I was with the public service.
And then I got on the board of the former students when I was with this other company,
It gave me a chance to be on the campus a lot more for board meetings and council meetings and committee meetings and so on.
So I had a chance to see what A&M was doing in the late 50s.
And the director of the Former Students Association?
It was Dick Hervey.
Dick Hervey.
Uh-huh.
See, McQuillan had been director from 28 to 47.
And then Hervey came in at 47.
And I joined him in 61.
That was a pretty awesome experience.
I'll tell you how this happened.
